newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine exporter sees 300,000 T cotton lint.
newsitem.headline: Argentine exporter sees 300,000 T cotton lint.

text.p: Argentina's 1996/97 cotton lint output will be around 300,000 tonnes, exporter Almiroty y Cia said Monday.
Some 700,000 tonnes of raw cotton were harvested by June 15 and only a few more days of fieldwork are now needed to finish collecting the crop, Almiroty said in a report.

The crop was badly hit by drought and heat in January after farmers had sown 900,000 hectares with cotton. This area was down from a record 1.0 million hectares in 1995/96, when lint output was 425,000 tonnes, but still well above the historical average.
Almiroty said this seasons's crop had not been a failure despite a large loss of tonnage to the heat.

"This crop cannot be described as bad, as for that to be the case both the volume and quality would have had to have failed, but the quality obtained up to now is good or more than acceptable," the report said.
The government's Agriculture Secretariat said in its weekly crop report last Friday that 78.4 percent of the nation's cotton had been harvested by June 13.
Argentina's textile industry usually buys about 100,000 tonnes of local cotton output, with the rest going for export.
Almiroty said in May that farmers were likely to sow another big area with cotton for the 1997/98 season, due to good prices and big recent investments in cotton machinery.
